content.description:
Start on the black rock and pull hard to gain the rest before entering the groove and steep roof above on jugs. 

Extension is 5.13b, 5m, 3 bolts to 2nd anchor – extension FA Remy Larocque

In the large corner about halfway between where the trail meets the crag and the large flat rock with a tree next to it. There will typically be a chalked "name plate" rock pointing to the climb. Start on the slab/arete.
Bolts.

Face climb the chimney on the left.


7 bolts

Tenuous opening moves through the first perma lead to jugs and a no-hands rest.  Good holds (small jugs and good crimps) for a few more bolts.  Just when you're feeling a bit pumped a good rest jug appears, which kicks off the crux sequence.



To the right of Pump Junkies.  A rock at the bottom identifies the route by name.

Permadraws

Follow enemy at the gates, then move right at the break. Hard to onsight.



Same start as enemy at the gates.

9 bolts

Easy climbing leads into a tricky corner.

anchors at top

The right most line at the monastery. Transition from the starting scoop to the crimpy slab and use dishes, edges and sidepulls to the top of the wall. 


Quickdraws

Start up the chimney and then veer right towards the Lorax while finishing out left.


8 bolts

Bouldery bottom leads to a no hands rest followed by a couple of bolts of awkward climbing on crappy feet.


5 bolts

An amazing rock climb.

Feeling good today? Want a confidence boost? Hop on this 13a. Nothing makes you feel better than pulling establishing yourself on a 13a by pulling few big moves on jugs, then getting smashed at the beta intensive opening boulder problem (about v5?). After solving this puzzle, you definitely earned a good shake on the upcoming jug. Thank God you just pulled that crux, because you can just run to the anchors now! Except not. The upper crux is a real show stopper. This section goes either left or right from the good jug, so pick your poison. Either way requires a powerful move to a good hold. The business is over now, but don't lose focus. The run to the anchors isn't free. A few pulls on large sloping edges takes you to the finish jugs.  You earn your 13 points on this one.

A great climb. I would totally recommend the climb for anyone who can work this grade. The clips are all pretty secure and well spaced with the cruxy sequences.

PS. It takes cool pictures.

Locate the prow. This is the second line from the left, starting on a large ledge and trending in a straight line just left of the arete. 
Permadraws + 1 optional first bolt

Dyno, break then boulder before chains.


6 bolts

Hard climbing off the ground on slopers and crimps gets you to the first permadraw (stick clipping this is recommended). Move through tricky sequences with sidepulls and underclings to the left of the bolt line. The crux comes below the last bolt, and involves dynamic movement on small crimps with poor feet. 



Starts off the big rock to the right of "Out of the Darkness". The righthand line, with permadraws.

Permadraws, plus one extra draw if you don't stick clip the first permadraw.

climbs.name: Out of the Darkness and Into the Light

content.description:
A fantastic technical climb. Easily establish in the dihedral by pulling on a large right facing rail in the corner. Navigate upwards through the dihedral and pull on the vertical face on a good hold. From here, you continue up along a large left trending rail with many positive holds and good feet. The last few moves to the chains are quite tricky, but good beta and hold-finding make it much easier.

A great climb, and a great first 12a for someone looking to break into the grade. There are generally good clipping stances and plenty of rests on this one.

There is a closed project extension on this route (08/18/19)

Start in the obvious dihedral in the middle of the cave, right around the corner from the prow. Go straight up the dihedral onto the face. 
Permadraws +1 quickdraw for the first bolt

Follow a line of left-trending cable draws past black streaks and a finger rail on the far right end of the Monastery. A sharp and awkward boulder crux guards entry to the top which offers some additional difficult climbing.  


Fixed draws, stick clip

A short but stout route. Begin on a left facing side pull rail, and work you way up some strong pulls on positive holds. The crux comes up at the second permadraw, as it involves a powerful pull to a good sloper. Rest a bit, and then enter another short bouldery sequence involving a good heel hook and strong committing move off an side pull/undercling to jug. Glorious jugs await afterwards to anchors. 

A great route for boulderers, as it is relatively short and the crux comes early. 

In the right flank past the cave. This climb sits in the tiny passageway between a rock and the cliff. 
Permadraws.

Pull over a bulge to a no hands rest before entering the steep headwall. Continue upwards trending to the right on good holds and decent feet. High clip the extended permadraw, then enter a reachy upper crux before the anchors. 

Permadraws

Up to the ledge, solve the powerful traverse right to gain a rest and an enjoyable finish.

anchor at top

Start on a good rail, and establish yourself on the climb by some easy pulls to big holds. Don't freak out as your greeted by the crux pretty low off the ground. Pull a few hard tricky  (maybe not the most comfortable) moves to a jug, then sit back and enjoy the ride by chugging out some comfy 5.9/10- moves through the end. Don't forget to check out the view from the top. 

To the right of Prancercise 12c in the right flank. 
10-12 quickdraws. This thing is overbolted.

Start on the some good crimps/edges on the large boulder, and top out. This line is unbroken seam that runs to the top. Technical laybacking and interesting body movement and positioning takes you to the top. The climbing startsbeasy, but becomes increasingly challenging and thoughtful as the seam thins a bit. The route builds well to a technical crux right before the anchors. Thoughtful movement, and well protected. A great climb. 

The lower holds in the crack are large, and you can easily establish yourself on the climb. There are two bolts on the lower boulder if you want to protect the opening, but the best option to eliminate rope drag is to either back clean the boulder or just not clip it entirely. I would recommend clipping up and back cleaning the first 2-3 bolts in the crack to eliminate rope drag. 

Right side of the crag, it starts on the face of the large boulder at the base of the crack. 
11 bolts.

Bouldery bottom to a no hands rest followed by a bouldery finish. 


5 bolts

The best warm up on the wall, easy climbing with rests leads to a short lived crux after the roof.

Bolts

Up and head right into the cave, break left onto the face and solve the sequential moves above.

Bolts

A great crag for people looking for some hard climbing. This crag has mostly 5.12s/+ for people looking for some hard climbing. There are a handful of moderate fun routes as well, but the mildly overhanging walls of The Monastery seem to favor the natural formation of harder climbs. Like many areas of chek, there are some routes with an initial pitch and an added extension for some extra credit. The climbing of this area is great and varied, demanding a wide skill set from powerful overhang to technical face, dihedrals and delicate slab (due to how the walls form very varied terrain, depending which area you find yourself in).

This area is broken up into 4 main parts. From left to right is, the left sector, the prow, the cave, And the right sector. The trail from the lower lot drops you off by the left sector. This wall is short and steep, a steep overhang with a ledge through the middle. Then is the prow, a solid continuous overhanging wall (about 30degrees). The next section around the prow is mostly vert, and well capped from the rain. The right sector has varied terrain. A few climbs run through the steeper wall(pump junkies 12d) and then around the corner are a few more climbs that go up the vert/slab ish face (satori 11a, water tension 12b)

Routes here generally get morning sun and afternoon shade, with the exception of Prancercise 12c that sits in the shade of nearby trees.

A free topo is available for download here (scroll down and click the link).
